content.body: does IE8 not support incremental loading of HTML content?
http://www.hixie.ch/tests/adhoc/dom/level0/timers/nph-009-demo.html for me in IE has it wait til the whole thing is loaded before parsing anything

Hixie: if we make createContextualFragment create scripts that are script-created and don't have their 'already started' flag set, would you be OK with adding a parameter to the HTML fragment parsing algorithm for controlling script execution prevention?
what's createContextualFragment()?
is it like insertAdjacentHTML()?
Hixie: it runs the fragment parsing algorithm with a string input and a context node and returns the corresponding DOM fragment
or is it the DOM Range thing?
Hixie: it's the Range thing
hmm
I think insertAdjacentHTML() should prevent execution
what's the use case for inserting scripts with createContextualFragment?
if we can get away with it just not executing scripts that sounds best to me
Hixie: currently, the main use case is emulating insertAdjacentHTML in browsers that don't have it *yet*
in that case, yeah, not running scripts seems best
(there are browsers with createContextualFragment but not insertAdjacentHTML?)
Hixie: but once insertAdjacentHTML is supported, if you think of createContextualFragment  as a standalone feature, it's a shortcut for building a DOM fragment
Hixie: Gecko
wow, i thought iAH was a mozillaism
shows what i know
Hixie: and if you built the DOM fragment manually, the scripts would be executable
so it's illogical for the shortcut to make scripts unexecutable
well the same could be said of innerHTML
the scripts are executable in Firefox 3.6 and in Opera
but it still blocks script execution
but not in WebKit
Hixie: only because other browsers cloned IE imprecisely and the execution prevention became the norm
for innerHTML that is
innerHTML not running scripts is definitely a plus in my book, given how much that simplifies so many complicated things
but anyway
how does innerHTML stop script creation currently?
does the fragment algorithm just block it?
if I were just lazy, preventing script execution for createContextualFragment would be easy, but I'm inclined to think that not preventing execution is the Right Thing
Hixie: the fragment parsing algorithm sets 'already started'
oh, i see, the parser does
hm, that makes parsing a flag a bit of a pain, but we could do it i guess
tbh i'd strongly recommend just not running scripts unless you have a very clear use case that needs it. (i mean an actual use case, not "build a DOM" or "emulate this other API")
running scripts in weird places is one of the main causes of there being arcane parts to the platform
Hixie: the annoying part is that people who've filed WebKit and Gecko bugs about this just say what behavior they want--not what their use case was
yeah, i hear ya
i'm battling the i18n wg as we speak over doing exactly that
Hixie: the current plan is the run scripts from fragments created by XSLTPrecessor, so we'd still have to support fragments with executable scripts
and of course manually built ones
does anyone actually use xslt to generate scripts?
that's just frightening
who knows what Dark Matter does with XSLTProcessor
instrument the code and find out
Hixie: as for scripts created via <?xml-stylesheet?>, there's a Chrome Experement doing that
which is why the issue is now on my plate
feel free to break chrome experiments
i'm happy to take the blame at google for that
Hixie: I believe that would be against our privacy principles to instrument code without a Test Pilot opt-in
sure, i wasn't suggesting doing it without user consent
i just meant in a special build or something
don't you have betas specifically for this purpose?
i mean, instrumented betas
not necessarily the main beta line
I'm not aware of Mozilla doing intrumented betas
ah
well
get the chrome team to do it
and even if we did, there'd be the problem of getting Dark Matter users to use them
abarth will likely be happy to set it up
what's Dark Matter? I thought you just meant random people Out There.
Hixie: enterprise intranets
or extranets
you're going to run scripts from fragments?
that seems crazy :)
yeah well if we're going to live in fear of breaking enterprise intranets, we'll just end up in analysis paralysis
abarth: is non-running in WebKit by design or by accident?
Hixie: why would be go ahead and break stuff that used to work just for the sake of making scripts run less?
s/be/we/
there are architectural problems with running scripts without a frame in webkit
the JavaScript engine can do it
abarth: oh, I don't mean running scripts while they aren't in a DOM that's in a browsing contenxt
but the code that knows how to talk to the JavaScript engine would be very confused
*context

hsivonen: making scripts run less seems like a goal in and of itself to me. certainly in weird places like xslt where the security and interoperability implications are rather esoteric and not necessarily understood by many people.
abarth: I mean running scripts when a fragment is inserted into a DOM that's being displayed in a browsing context
which reminds me that I was about to file a spec bug about not running scripts that are in a document but the document doesn't have a browsing context
ah, that's technically feasible
abarth: the specific case we're talking about instrumenting is the output of XSLT transforms that contain scripts
abarth: see http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/
scripts = script tags ?
or do inline event handlers count too?
i think in gecko it creates an actual dom
abarth: script nodes
abarth: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/createContextualFragment.html
anyway, if xslt is defined in terms of just creating a dom or a serialisation that's then parsed, it seems that this all just falls out of the spec as is
abarth: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/XSLTProcessor-transformToFragment.html
how is xslt defined? (is it defined?)
abarth: those two run the script in Firefox 3.6 and in Opera 10.63 but not in WebKit
i think all these code paths chase down the same path as innerHTML
for inline scripts
the parser is responsible for kicking off script execution
abarth: it's easy to see how you'd accidentally make createContextualFragment prevent execution by reusing innerHTML infrastructure
but it doesn't do that if there's no frame
abarth: but http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/XSLTProcessor-transformToFragment.html is different
to answer your question, i have no idea whether its intentional
abarth: ok
i think XSLT was added because someone at IBM complained
i'm not sure how many people actually care about it
IE's behaviour on http://www.hixie.ch/tests/adhoc/dom/level0/timers/nph-010-demo.html is shocking to me
does IE really wait until the document is entirely loaded before doing anything?
surely i'm just doing something wrong
Hixie: fwiw, I believe the closest thing to an XSLTProcessor spec is https://developer.mozilla.org/en/Using_the_Mozilla_JavaScript_interface_to_XSL_Transformations
well transformToDocument should definitely not run the scripts

but i guess if you want the "already executed" flag to not be set, so long as the execution only happens once the stuff is inserted into the real document and not the innerHTML document, i guess we could finagle that

it'd be a bit of a hack... the reason the spec right now sets "already executed" the way it does, in addition to being ok for compat for innerHTML, is that the Document it's parsing into has no global scope
so it can't run script anyway
what's the benefit of running scripts?
it's unclear to me that there is one
abarth: at least jQuery goes through trouble to make itself a fragment parser that does run scripts
i'd much rather just not run them
interesting
JohnResig: do you have input for use cases for or against createContextualFragment creating executable scripts?
i still think we should have some way of parsing a fragment that lets you whitelist tags and attributes
its not really related, but its very popular in server-side frameworks

though it's unclear if jQuery would benefit from the behavior that would result from createContextualFragment creating executable script nodes, because those scripts wouldn't execute in order when the fragment is inserted to the DOM
it would be so nice if people filing these bugs said more about their higher-level use cases
agreed
I asked the reporters to elaborate on their use cases in both bugzillas
whatwg.org is really really slow for me. just me?
are there any plans for localization eg. on input type="number"s or type="date"s?
hmm i realized that importScripts is sync
Oh
I was just going to say I liked that idea
No I don't anymore
*Now
zcorpan: whatwg.org seems to be responding normally to me
at least the spec, wiki, and mailing-list archives
MikeSmith: whatwg.org is not working properly for me
"The server at www.whatwg.org is taking too long to respond."
trries some other browsers
hsivonen: seems to be working the same for me in every browser I've tried so far
which is to say, responding normally
including in WebKit with the "Disable Caches" option set
(which seems to be the bestest was to test if stuff is actually being served from the source and not from a cache)
is an Opera 11 snapshot available yet?
no
ok
MikeSmith: http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/ is the best place to look, in general
ok
btw, if  there is somebody in particular to whom I should address Dragonfly bugs, please let me know
*Dragonfly bug reports
Hallvord?
oh wait
"If you are on BitBucket please follow Opera Dragonfly, and feel free to report new issues there."
http://my.opera.com/hallvors/blog/2010/10/20/dragonfly-feedback-follow-up
so I will feel free and do that
virtuelv: ^
ah
damn, there's like 7 different dragonfly branches at bitbucker
bitbucket
jgraham: thanks
ah, Christian Krebs
I guess
hmm. I wonder if I'm testing IE9 wrong when I try to remove documentElement from a document
nope, that wasn't the problem
I see no logic in script execution in WebKit
most things make scripts not run, but this doesn't: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/createDocument.html
Anyone know about the html5lib for PHP?
as far as I can't tell there isn't
no HTML5 parser for PHP
Yes, it exists
No I don't know much about it
rmccue: Yes.
crash\: Part of http://code.google.com/p/html5lib/
gsnedders: Why, hello you.
rmccue: ;P
ah
I though this is only Python
rmccue: Where do you think I hang out, if not channels like this? :)
gsnedders: I had no idea you were awake.
rmccue: It's midday.
0.1 pretty outdated
But yes, ask your question.
It's returning blank DOMDocument/DOMNodeList objects for me.
Oh, nice.
Disclaimer: I've not touched html5lib/php in over a year
Wait, maybe not.
You mention the latter on a regular interval.
In a, "hey, rmccue, you should take it over" way :P
OK, nevermind, it is working. PHP just sucks.
Sure, but I hardly have time for anything else, let alone a HTML5 parser. :P
rmccue: Bogus bug report.
Status: Invalid. Reason: PEBKAC
Hixie: does anyone actually use xslt to generate scripts?
hixie: you mean generate an (x)html script element in the result document from xslt? if so yes, if you mean something else then I don't know:-)
david_carlisle: it's known that people use <?xml-stylesheet?>-invoked XSLT to create (X)HTML script elements
david_carlisle: however, the interesting bit is if people use XSLTProcessor to create script nodes
david_carlisle: like this: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/scripts/XSLTProcessor-transformToFragment.html
hsivonen: people who use xslt clearly have taste and don't go in for all this imperative  DOM scripting p.appendChild nonsense.  (This isn't being archived is it:-)
I have no idea, I doubt there are many instances of that,  would it have been possible to get something like that working in previous versions of ie and firefox 9say)
cross browser conserns tend to limit people being too adventurous in teh way they mix script and xslt in my experience
I think the xslt+scripting has gotten better support across browsers in the last few years
david_carlisle: I haven't tested, but I assume that in IE it's not possible to move nodes from ActiveX-owned DOMs to the browser DOMs
and browsers have node-set() and document() sanely supportd
david_carlisle: so if one used the IE XSLT API instead of XSLTProcessor(), adopting the node would fail
does anybody know if there has actually be any serious new movement in TC39 towards getting a binary data type added?
is it on the agenda for the f2f next month?
I could ask on xsl-list but that's probably not really the right audience, I think such usage is more likely buried in the libraries like sarissa that tried to hide a lot of the complexity.
hsivonen: thanks for http://hg.mozilla.org/projects/htmlparser/rev/b0fe4ac38a02

annevk: â†‘
what's the bug?
I can fix it in place
if you give me a diff
or if you check in a fix i will make a diff and apply it to the WD

MikeSmith, if you can remove the line
  • s
MikeSmith, <s> was mentioned both in changed and absent elements, it should be removed from absent
hey, are there any thoughts about bringing in localization for eg. type="numbers" and type="date"s?
that's a UA feature
the format defined in the specification is for submission and the server only
FWIW, UA-side localization has the same problem as trying to localize the display format of <time>

MikeSmith, gotta go now, but it's the line "
  • s" afaik
annevk: yeah, got it
if you go to a U.S. English site and see a number field that says "2,000" what does it mean?
have already checked in the change to the WD
MikeSmith, great thanks
does it mean two thousand in the site's locale?
MikeSmith, ttyl
cheers
or 2 in the UA's locale?
hsivonen, I think we should base UA localization on the document language
hsivonen, rather than the user language
annevk: so UAs would need a database of number formats associated with all existing language tags?
yeah
OTOH, for a date picker it would be OK to display the month name in the user's language as a word, since there'd be no ambiguity
ehh... there still might be a need to input a date in an arbitrary format that is not the same as the document's language
antti_s: the expected UI for input type=date is a date picker
with date pickers there's the issue of starting weeks on Sunday vs. Monday
hsivonen: so the date format used after selecting the date is a browser vendor's problem
used/displayed
input type=week uses ISO weeks, but input type=date for en-US could conceivable use Sunday-based week layout
antti_s: the date format communicated between the browser and the site is always YYYY-MM-DD
antti_s: browsers are allowed to compete on how they render it to the users
hsivonen: ok, 10-4 :)
hsivonen: should the similar approach be used also on type=numbers
antti_s: see Opera for how type=date is supposed to work (except it should be prettier than in Opera)
hsivonen: currently it bugs me that using commas as decimal separators does not work, apparently because of the sanitization algorithm
antti_s: the UA is allowed to expose a decimal comma to the user as long as a decimal point is used between the browser and the server
wishes all countries just standardized on a decimal point so we could get rid of this gratuitous incompatibility
hsivonen: ok, thanks a much, this was really valuable information (that i didn't seem to find myself from the specs) :)
hsivonen: can you give any pointers to where i should look up information related to this UA/datepicker/decimal-separator stuff?
antti_s: the rendering constrains are pretty much what's said in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-input-element-as-domain-specific-widgets
antti_s: also see the rightmost column in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#attr-input-type-keywords
antti_s: the spec isn't particularly clear on what's allowed here, because readers are supposed to know that the spec doesn't try to prescribe browser UI
Hixie: the spec could be clearer here
hsivonen: thank you, very much appreciated. i'll look in to those.
antti_s: filed a bug as http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=11107
I wonder if bugzilla recycled the id of deleted issues which were initially created as spam. (not very important though, just curious)
is getting tired of the bug spam being posted to public-html
Oh, Julian already said that
filters the bugs into a different folder
I actually think this setup is much better than it was before
Although of course it would be even better with no spam
doesn't move his mails in folders
hmm not exactly true
procmail is moving all my mails into monthly dated space folders. /2010/09/, /2010/10/, etc.
Eep
How do you live with that?
then I create dynamic/smart folders
karlcow, how do you do so?
because my contexts evolve little by little
so I destroy/create dynamic folders
karlcow: Presumably those are limited to a single client though?
mostly filters by mailing list into honest-to-goodness imap folders
Apple Mail with an imap server :)
Oh, my!
I have done this organization forâ€¦ 3 years now (I think), I have never been happier. A lot, lot better. One mail can be in many different contexts
Maybe you are just ahppier by coincidence and if you used the old mail classification scheme you would be even happier still :)
Coincidences do simply not exist.
I have mostly all my mails since around 1991 (except those I have erase by choice or by mistake), and dated space is a metaphor which suits me.
it has another benefits, it limits the number of files on the filesystems by folder. The 500,000+ emails are nicely distributed
Au revoir
Philip`: I *love* seeing all the mail.  What I don't love is that almost all of the anon mail from the W3C spec is spam.  We should just turn that one off.

gsnedders: I did the IR with 6 because I thought I had to use a public build.  There was some discussion about using more recent builds, but I didn't see anything about changing the requirements written in the spec, so I went with what the spec said.
And 6 was the public build a few weeks ago.
TabAtkins_: How can you tell it's from the W3C spec?
Philip`: They all have the section of http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#top
I thought that the w3c version always did that?
might be wrong.
In any case, flagging anything from #top specially so it needs moderation before hitting the list would fix almost all of the spam problems.
has no idea
Alternately, just not allowing bugs to be filed on #top.
Philip`: Yeah, there's no #top in the whatwg copy, and the w3c comments form explicitly indicates its id as "top" in a hidden input.
Isn't 80% spam considerably better than email in general?
Of course no one has tried to use it for really maliciuos purposes yet
If you don't account for spam filtering, yes.
(and I agree it should be fixed, in case there is any doubt)
80% spam actually ending up in anyone's mailbox is a lot worse than e-mail in general, I hope.
Sure
One could try using the same spam filtering here
If one wanted a complex technical solution
we reduced the spam on the whatwg form by having some JS count the spaces and stuff
we could do the same here if that would help
i just tried a quick hack
I did notice that many of the spam bugs do not contain a space
that didn't have JS
but i can add JS
I was actually just going to suggest some "minimal useful comment" metric
as a simple technical solution
i'll hack something in
I once had a comment rejected for being too short (in the WHATWG version), so don't we have such a thing already?
see above, teh w3c one doesn't have that code

Anything to stop the "asdfasdf"-style comments would be greatly welcome.  It would be extra awesome if it silently discarded messages that super-failed the metric you used, to discourage just altering the message to have more asdf.  (Alerting about the message when it merely somewhat fails the metric is good, though.)
I think you should always alert.
If it's a real human doing it, it's unlikely to be a big problem.
Unless we get hardcore vandalism problems.
In which case, reverting to the previous hurdle of "have to email the group or submit a bug yourself" is sufficient.
Yes.
But that's not necessary yet.
wonders how far along the path of "determine if a given string is likely a valid sentence in English" current AI/NLP will get you
Not as a very practical solution but because it seems interesting
You could probably get a long way just with a spellchecker
I forgive Google Safe Browsing for all the false positives I've ever seen from it.
jgraham: just sample all text from digg.com and match against it. if it matches it is *not* valid english :)
